results.title: Law of the Journey
results.brief_description: Weiwei’s installation work Law of the Journey continues the artist’s exploration of the the global refugee crisis and its impact on the people involved. The work features a 196 foot inflatable sculpture, along with walls of photographs and moving image projections.

constellations_other.name: Seeking asylum
constellations_other.description: Chauka Please Tell Us the Time was covertly filmed on a smartphone inside the Manus Island Detention Centre and sent via WhatsApp.

results.title: Law of desire
results.brief_description: The flamboyant Spanish director, Pedro Almodovar, is one of contemporary cinema’s comic masters. “Law of Desire” is an exquisite farce about the hypocrisy of machismo, whether in its homosexual or heterosexual guise. Pablo is a famous “erotic film-maker” who enjoys a discreet gay lifestyle. But when the beautiful Antonio falls for him Pablo’s world is turned upside down by the young man’s persistent and obsessive attentions. Very soon Pablo is involved in a crime of passion and his beautiful transsexual sister Tina is the only one who can save him. A festive, colourful mixture of melodrama and hilarity “Law of Desire ” celebrates sexual difference while simultaneously poking fun at the conventions of romantic love. With Antonio Banderas, Carmen Maura and Bibi Anderson.

results.title: Law Affecting Journalism
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journalism Resource Tapes”.
Creighton Burns, Editor of “The Age”, and Harry Gordon, former Editor-in-Chief at “The Herald and Weekly Times”, discuss the law of libel, defamation, and the problems and benefits of these laws in the journalist’s world.

results.title: Law
results.creator_credit: Career Productions and Mutual Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Is this your career series”.
A vocational guidance film showing the different responsibilities carried by the barrister and the solicitor. Discusses opportunities available in the practice of law, including services to business and commerce.

results.title: Laurette
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Barrie Howells and Pierre Lasry
results.brief_description: This is a portrayal of a young woman left alone to cope with family problems. Laurette is a young secretary, separated from her husband, with a daughter to bring up. Her thoughts, feelings and fears are shown. As she tries to make sense of the broken reality of her life, she must each day convince herself that life can go on while she provides a home for her child, that living as a “solo” parent is possible. (Awards: Washington)

results.title: Laurel Martyn
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers”.
Laurel Martyn trained in London with Phyllis Bedells and was awarded a choreographic scholarship under the auspices of Ninette de Valois. In this interview, Martyn recalls the highlights of her performing career with the “Sadler’s Wells Ballet” in England and the “Borovansky Ballet” in Australia and discusses her teaching method and philosophy. Through her company, “Ballet Vistoria”, Martyn encouraged the development of a distinctively Australian style of dance and introduced ballet to thousands of school children. Researched and interviewed by James Murdoch.

results.title: Laurel and Hardy: Wrong again. Angora love. Do detectives think
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Hal Roach, Leo McCarey and Lewis R. Foster
results.brief_description: Three classic comic shorts from Laurel and Hardy. In “Wrong again” (20 mins. 1929), a comedy with a surrealistic edge, stable-hands Stan and Ollie respond to a millionaire’s offer of a reward for ‘Blue Boy’, a missing painting, by delivering ‘Blue Boy’ a horse. They find an instruction to leave ‘Blue Boy’ on the piano. In “Angora love” (20 mins. 1929), Stan and Ollie are adopted by a runaway goat. In “Do detectives think” (20 mins. 1927), the boys play inept detectives hired to guard a judge who is the target of an escaped convict.
results.title_for_label: Laurel and Hardy: Wrong again. Angora love. Do detectives think

results.title: Laurel and Hardy: Way out west. Big business
results.creator_credit: Hal Roach Studios, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Stan Laurel, Hal Roach, James W. Horne and Leo McCarey
results.brief_description: Two comedies from slapstick team Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy. “Way out West” - Stan and Ollie head out West as prospectors and when their partner Cy dies, they are entrusted to deliver the deed for valuable land to Cy’s daughter Mary. After all manner of mishaps, the pair are swindled by a crooked bar owner and his wife Lola. When Stan and Ollie realise the duplicity they have to steal the deed back, returning it to its rightful owner. Classic scenes include Stan being tickled into submission by Lola and eating his hat after losing a bet. “Way out west” is arguably one of Laurel and Hardy’s best-loved comedies, which can be viewed on this DVD in the colourised version or in original black and white. “Big business” - one of Laurel and Hardy’ last silent shorts has been identified as a masterful example of the genre. Laurel and Hardy are door-to-door Christmas tree salesmen who successfully offend potential customers, one of whom becomes enraged when the pair appears determined to harass him. As the feud escalates Laurel and Hardy commit a multitude of destructive acts, which results in the demolition of the owner’s house. He in turn unleashes a torrent of angst against the aforementioned tree and the hapless duo’s car, as a bemused crowd gather to watch.
results.title_for_label: Laurel and Hardy: Way out west. Big business

results.title: Laurel and Hardy: The Music box. Busy bodies. Towed in a hole
results.creator_credit: Hal Roach Incorporated, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Hal Roach, James Parrott, Lloyd French and George Marshall
results.brief_description: Three short films from classic slapstick comedy duo Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy. “The Music Box” - Stan and Ollie are deliverymen whose task is to deliver a valuable piano to an irascible professor. The pair struggles with the piano up and down a daunting set of concrete stairs, causing a slew of unmitigated disasters once finally inside the house. This short film was honoured with an Oscar for “Best Live-Action Short Subject.” “Busy bodies” - short film brimming with sight gags, sees Laurel and Hardy driving to work in an old jalopy causing mayhem, distracting others with a gramophone hooked up under the bonnet. Once at work, the havoc continues as they irritate the foreman and cause non-stop harm to one another. Some of the gags recall the complex set-ups of Bester Keaton’s finest work. “Towed in a hole” - short that ably illustrates the comic chemistry between the two stars. Laurel and Hardy are successful fish salesmen; Stan decides they can increase their profit by cutting out the middleman and catching their own fish off the jetty. Ollie one-ups him by buying a holey boat, over which the two bicker like children, in their attempt to repair it. Immensely funny physical and inspired comedy.
results.title_for_label: Laurel and Hardy: The Music box. Busy bodies. Towed in a hole
